quotes.topic_title: Why funnels and MQLs/SQLs are flawed
quotes.text: The problem with funnels and pirate metrics and the favorites that I love to pick on are MQLs and SQLs is that nobody knows what those mean.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Challenges the usefulness of common growth labels/metrics by pointing out they’re often undefined and inconsistently applied.

quotes.topic_title: Why funnels and MQLs/SQLs are flawed
quotes.text: It assumes that all customers and all products are the same.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Highlights a core flaw in funnel thinking: it overgeneralizes and can lead to one-size-fits-all tactics instead of customer-specific approaches.

quotes.topic_title: Why funnels and MQLs/SQLs are flawed
quotes.text: It puts businesses at the center of the business versus putting customers at the center. Right?
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A memorable reframing toward customer-led growth: optimize around customers rather than internal business stages.

quotes.topic_title: Why funnels and MQLs/SQLs are flawed
quotes.text: And the vast, vast majority of these models don't take post-acquisition, retention, expansion, all of that into account.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Actionable reminder for SaaS teams to extend growth models beyond acquisition to include retention and expansion.

quotes.topic_title: Why funnels and MQLs/SQLs are flawed
quotes.text: So yeah, in a nutshell, funnels are bad.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A punchy, quotable conclusion that encapsulates the segment’s critique of funnel-based growth thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: my goal here is to help you get better at the craft of building and growing products.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames product growth as a learnable craft, setting a practitioner-oriented lens for the episode.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: she often finds huge unlocks and opportunities often doubling or tripling conversion in various points in their product flows.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete outcome (2–3x conversion) that signals where to look for leverage: specific points in product flows.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: she shares the exact process that she goes through to help companies figure out where their biggest growth opportunities lie, and also how to execute on them.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a repeatable methodology—diagnose the biggest opportunities and pair it with execution steps.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We chat about how to identify your most important customers, how to very practically map their journey through your flows and set goals, and then execute on your ideas.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Outlines an actionable sequence: prioritize customers → map journey → set goals → execute, which practitioners can adopt as a workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What we've always thought of Amplitude is being about supporting the full product loop, think collect data, inform bets, ship experiments, and learn.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: A concise end-to-end framework for product growth that teams can use to structure their analytics and experimentation workflow.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So the big aha was seen how many customers were using Amplitude to analyze experiments, use segments for outreach, and send data to other destinations. Experimenting CDP came out of listening to and observing our customers.
quotes.speaker: John Cutler
quotes.context: Highlights a customer-led methodology for product expansion: observe real usage patterns and build adjacent capabilities from them.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Two, they treat AG1 like a software product. Apparently, they're on their 52nd iteration and they're constantly evolving it based on the latest science, research studies, and internal testing that they do.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable example of applying continuous iteration and evidence-driven improvement (common in software) to a physical product.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One, with a small scoop that dissolves in water, you are absorbing 75 vitamins, minerals, probiotics, and adaptogens.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific, concrete data point that makes the value proposition measurable and easy to compare against alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: Gia’s career journey and Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: I was starting to get burnout, I was doing a lot, and I was like, "What would it feel like to sink my teeth into one brand?"
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A practical career/operating insight about reducing context switching and going deeper on one product to avoid burnout and increase impact.

quotes.topic_title: Gia’s career journey and Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: I had this little catalyst moment where I joined Twitter in late 2008, and I discovered the tech scene and startups.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Highlights how a single exposure point (a platform/community) can catalyze a major career shift into startups.

quotes.topic_title: Gia’s career journey and Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: we started pairing up on working with companies and sort of married her customer research background in my strategy, marketing background.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A simple operating model for customer-led growth: combine customer research with strategy/marketing execution.

quotes.topic_title: Gia’s career journey and Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: And we developed this framework that we now use when we work with predominantly B2B SaaS companies, is who we work with right now.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Signals a repeatable methodology (a framework) tailored to B2B SaaS teams rather than one-off consulting tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Why the consultancy is called Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: But the problem with funnels and pirate metrics and the favorites that I love to pick on are MQLs and SQLs is that nobody knows what those mean.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Challenges common SaaS/marketing metrics by pointing out their ambiguity, pushing practitioners to define or replace them with clearer measures.

quotes.topic_title: Why the consultancy is called Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: It puts every customer in the same sort of buckets. It assumes that all customers and all products are the same.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A practical critique that encourages segmentation and customer-specific journeys instead of one-size-fits-all funnel stages.

quotes.topic_title: Why the consultancy is called Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: It puts businesses, or they, I should say, puts businesses at the center of the business versus putting customers at the center.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model shift: design growth systems around customer outcomes rather than internal business stages.

quotes.topic_title: Why the consultancy is called Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: recurring revenue businesses, you cannot think about marketing and growth and the business overall as ending at acquisition. Otherwise, you're not in business anymore.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for SaaS teams to prioritize post-acquisition retention/expansion as core to growth, not an afterthought.

quotes.topic_title: Why the consultancy is called Forget The Funnel
quotes.text: They also leave the problem stage out. So the world that customers are living in prior to discovering you, which is a really critical, that context is unbelievably valuable, especially for marketing.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Introduces a key pre-discovery stage practitioners can research and message to, improving positioning and demand creation.

quotes.topic_title: Typical growth impact: messaging, onboarding, activation
quotes.text: I would say, far in a way the biggest, most immediate impact of the type of work that we do is realigning with that ideal customer.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Highlights ideal-customer realignment as the highest-leverage starting point for growth work.

quotes.topic_title: Typical growth impact: messaging, onboarding, activation
quotes.text: Generally, the lowest hanging fruit outcome is realigning around better positioning and messaging.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance that messaging/positioning fixes are often the fastest path to measurable impact.

quotes.topic_title: Typical growth impact: messaging, onboarding, activation
quotes.text: We shortened the trial from 30 days to seven. The conversion on the website went up with this new messaging by 89%. But the thing that I love the most about that particular story is that we didn't even touch anything after the signup experience. We hadn't even gotten there and the trial-to-paid conversion rate increased 40%, and we didn't touch it. It was just because a more qualified, better fit customer was coming through the door.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive example showing that better pre-signup messaging can lift downstream conversion without changing onboarding or product.

quotes.topic_title: Typical growth impact: messaging, onboarding, activation
quotes.text: With Autobooks, the product usage of the North Star product usage jumped by 300% or something within quite a short period of time after rolling out email onboarding to support that product experience.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Concrete data point linking onboarding (email) improvements to large gains in North Star usage.

quotes.topic_title: Typical growth impact: messaging, onboarding, activation
quotes.text: I know SparkToro as well, which I think we might end up talking about again when we talk about the process, they doubled their trial-to-paid conversion rate when we worked with them because of post acquisition optimization to their messaging.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Example of post-acquisition messaging optimization driving a 2x trial-to-paid lift.

quotes.topic_title: How common are “double conversion” opportunities?
quotes.text: Every company we've ever worked with has learned something new about their customers that they can apply at some juncture of their customer's experience, whether or not it is in campaigns to reach the right people out in the world, whether or not it's doing a better job with their messaging and positioning on their website, or their go-to market or acquisition strategy on their website using a sandbox account or getting a faux freemium account to let people kick the tires of their product prior to getting on a sales call.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Highlights that customer research consistently yields actionable improvements across the funnel, including a concrete tactic (sandbox/faux freemium) to reduce friction before sales.

quotes.topic_title: How common are “double conversion” opportunities?
quotes.text: The post-acquisition experience I'm talking about, it is so often an afterthought somehow where that additional of layer... I think part of the reason why it's an afterthought is because product onboarding in particular, and you've probably heard this too, it tends to be kind of like no man's land. Who owns that?
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Calls out a common organizational failure mode—unclear ownership of onboarding/activation—which creates latent growth opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: How common are “double conversion” opportunities?
quotes.text: Is it marketing? If it's freemium, in my opinion it should be marketing because freemium is a marketing tool, but not everybody subscribes to that.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Offers a clear ownership heuristic for freemium onboarding that challenges teams who default to product-led ownership.

quotes.topic_title: How common are “double conversion” opportunities?
quotes.text: So we end up seeing a messy middle there because there's no natural handoff. So pretty well, every company that we've worked with has had an opportunity to improve, especially product onboarding and product activation.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Names the “messy middle” as the systemic gap between functions and points practitioners to onboarding/activation as high-leverage improvement areas.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb storyboard moment: customer-journey alignment
quotes.text: It was a customer journey that was focused on the customer. So versus that pirate metrics problem or that the typical buyer's journey problem that I was talking about earlier, it was the complete reverse of that.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A clear, contrarian reframing: map the journey from the customer’s perspective rather than funnel/metrics-first thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb storyboard moment: customer-journey alignment
quotes.text: It was illustrated. The emotional journey was part of it. The role that Airbnb played as a direct touchpoint and also indirect, what was going on in the person's life that had nothing to do outside of Airbnb, which I thought was really interesting.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A practical methodology for journey mapping: include emotions and off-platform context, not just product touchpoints.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb storyboard moment: customer-journey alignment
quotes.text: the three of us locked ourselves in the room for two days and made our own.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A concrete execution tactic: get cross-functional leaders to co-create the journey map to drive buy-in and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb storyboard moment: customer-journey alignment
quotes.text: it made communicating with especially the product team and the engineering team a lot easier for me. So we were using a shared language.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Highlights the operational payoff: a shared customer-journey artifact becomes a common language across teams.

quotes.topic_title: Airbnb storyboard moment: customer-journey alignment
quotes.text: Airbnb hired a full-time storyboard artist from Pixar to draw these key frames.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific example showing how seriously Airbnb invested in making the customer journey vivid and actionable.

quotes.topic_title: Process overview and SparkToro case setup
quotes.text: Well, the process is pretty straightforward. At the highest level, the idea is, understand your best customers, map their experience, like we were just talking about, map their experience through the lens of delivering value to them, make it measurable, and then evaluate what you're doing today that is out of alignment with that.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A concise, end-to-end methodology for customer-led growth: identify best customers, map value delivery, quantify it, then fix misalignments.

quotes.topic_title: Process overview and SparkToro case setup
quotes.text: But the people that were signing up for their free product weren't converting to paid in the way that they believed they could.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A concrete example of a common growth bottleneck—strong acquisition and activation, weak free-to-paid conversion—setting up where to focus diagnosis.

quotes.topic_title: Process overview and SparkToro case setup
quotes.text: So we decided to work with them and basically go to the source and find out, from SparkToro's best customers, what can we learn from them that we can then reflect back in the product experience and the customer experience for them?
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to diagnose conversion issues by learning directly from best customers and translating insights into product and customer experience changes.

quotes.topic_title: Process overview and SparkToro case setup
quotes.text: So yes, interviews are ideal always, but we did think that we could learn a ton from surveys to then, if needed, double down with interviews.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A pragmatic research sequencing approach: start with scalable surveys, then use interviews selectively to deepen what you learn.

quotes.topic_title: Process overview and SparkToro case setup
quotes.text: Now, what I mean by best customers is those that get a ton of value from your product as of exist today, pay obviously. They're happy. They're low maintenance. And very importantly, they signed up for your product recently enough that they remember what life was like before.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A clear operational definition of “best customers” for research sampling, including the often-missed criterion of recency to capture accurate before/after context.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done research: surveys and best-customer criteria
quotes.text: So yes, interviews are ideal always, but we did think that we could learn a ton from surveys to then, if needed, double down with interviews. We didn't end up actually needing to run the interviews because the surface that we ran were pretty decisive and clear in terms of what we learned.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Contrarian take that well-designed surveys can sometimes replace interviews when patterns are decisive, saving time while still producing clear JTBD insights.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done research: surveys and best-customer criteria
quotes.text: So what we did was, we identified SparkToro's best customers. Now, what I mean by best customers is those that get a ton of value from your product as of exist today, pay obviously. They're happy. They're low maintenance. And very importantly, they signed up for your product recently enough that they remember what life was like before.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Defines a practical “best customer” sampling framework for JTBD research that improves signal quality by focusing on high-value, low-friction, recent buyers.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done research: surveys and best-customer criteria
quotes.text: So generally, we say that's in the three to six-month range. Because if you go to somebody that's been your customer for two years, they're just going to fill answers with what they think might have been going on in their life. But if you ask customers who remember what life was like before, you're going to get a lot more interesting responses, a lot more accurate depiction of what was going on.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Gives a concrete recency window (3–6 months) and the reasoning—memory accuracy—for selecting respondents in JTBD surveys.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done research: surveys and best-customer criteria
quotes.text: But also, what were they looking for in a solution? What were the must-haves for them versus what were some of the anxieties that they had, some deal breakers, things like that? So basically unpacking what is it that was critical for them in their solution. And then of course, what is it they're able to do now that they weren't able to do before. So that desired outcome.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Provides a JTBD question checklist (must-haves, anxieties/deal breakers, desired outcomes) that practitioners can directly use to structure surveys.

quotes.topic_title: Jobs-to-be-done research: surveys and best-customer criteria
quotes.text: So out of that, we identified a couple of different options, a couple of different jobs, customer jobs, and we have to prioritize one, of course, because if you start right off the bat with like, "Okay, we're going to solve for all of these different customers jobs," then you end up not being as resonant. You can't be as effective. So we focused in on one.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Emphasizes the focus principle in positioning: pick one primary job to maximize resonance rather than trying to serve multiple jobs at once.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing which customer job to prioritize
quotes.text: Maybe the most important one is that they have an urgent problem. So the whole pain killer versus vitamin thing, you always want to be selling a pain killer.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A clear prioritization heuristic for choosing which customer job to lead with: optimize for urgency and painkiller-level need.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing which customer job to prioritize
quotes.text: Who has a high retention or even expansion potential is also really advantageous for very obvious reasons.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Emphasizes selecting customer jobs that compound via retention and expansion, not just initial conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing which customer job to prioritize
quotes.text: So sometimes you might want to prioritize one customer job over another, if those customers congregate in a way that make them really easy to market to. That's an advantage.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Introduces reachability/distribution efficiency as a deciding criterion when picking a primary customer job.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing which customer job to prioritize
quotes.text: Or another advantage, and this was the case for SparkToro, is you have an unfair advantage with this market in some way.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Highlights “unfair advantage” as a practical filter for job prioritization, grounded in a real SparkToro example.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing which customer job to prioritize
quotes.text: It's not that you wouldn't necessarily still be able to solve for that other customer job, it's just not the one that you would lead with.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A counterintuitive clarification that prioritizing one job is about sequencing and positioning, not permanently excluding other jobs.

quotes.topic_title: From data to strategy: avoid tactical piecemeal growth
quotes.text: So the challenge that happened so, so often, and I mean this happens with a lot of teams, particularly marketers fall victim to this tactical way of approaching things and piecemealing things, piecemealing campaigns or programs to prove that we're doing something and we're driving up numbers, and they don't take big enough sort of swings.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Calls out a common growth trap—tactical, piecemeal optimization—arguing for bigger strategic swings instead of incremental activity.

quotes.topic_title: From data to strategy: avoid tactical piecemeal growth
quotes.text: So this is like, zoom out for a second, figure out who is it that you even want coming through the front door.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A practical directive to start growth work by defining the ideal customer to attract, before optimizing conversion mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: From data to strategy: avoid tactical piecemeal growth
quotes.text: I mean, the social media platform tool that I mentioned, the trial-to-pay conversion rate bumped up 40% because a higher qualified person comes through the front door.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Concrete example showing that improving lead quality can dramatically lift conversion without product tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: From data to strategy: avoid tactical piecemeal growth
quotes.text: We're not at personas. We don't care about personas at all.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Counterintuitive stance that challenges persona-led marketing in favor of a different organizing principle.

quotes.topic_title: From data to strategy: avoid tactical piecemeal growth
quotes.text: So it's identifying, okay, for this ideal customer, what are those key milestones in their relationship with our product? What are those big of leaps of faith is how I describe it.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Introduces a journey-mapping framework focused on milestones and “leaps of faith” to guide onboarding and activation strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Mapping the customer journey into milestones
quotes.text: So it's identifying, okay, for this ideal customer, what are those key milestones in their relationship with our product? What are those big of leaps of faith is how I describe it.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Frames journey mapping as identifying the customer’s key “leaps of faith,” a practical way to pinpoint what marketing and product must de-risk.

quotes.topic_title: Mapping the customer journey into milestones
quotes.text: In general though, what we would do is, we'd break it down into a struggle phase and evaluation phase and a growth phase.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Provides a simple, reusable three-phase structure teams can apply to map any customer journey.

quotes.topic_title: Mapping the customer journey into milestones
quotes.text: So we have worked with companies where the evaluation phase has been three or four milestones, I would always default to as few as possible.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to keep milestone maps minimal unless complexity truly demands more steps.

quotes.topic_title: Mapping the customer journey into milestones
quotes.text: So you want to get them to that product activation really, really quickly.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Emphasizes speed-to-first-value as a core lever for improving conversion and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Mapping the customer journey into milestones
quotes.text: We often talk about it and describe it as the story of how I met and fell in love with your product.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that helps teams craft journey maps as a narrative rather than a checklist of actions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Maven is a cohort-based learning platform where you learn alongside peers with a direct connection to your instructor.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Defines the core learning model (cohort + peer learning + instructor access) that practitioners can use as a blueprint for designing education or enablement programs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 10,000 people from Airbnb to Coinbase to Google to Tesla have taken courses from real experts and operators that have spent decades honing their craft.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point and credibility signal for cohort-based upskilling led by experienced operators.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The research that we do, we basically take all the responses, we identify the critical patterns, and that's how we identify the customer job.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Outlines a practical methodology for turning qualitative research into a clear Jobs-to-be-Done definition via pattern-finding.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: From those critical patterns, if we segment down just that customer job, we can look at responses and say, "Okay, here's what they're likely doing when they're out in the world experiencing this problem. This is how they described the pain of their current solution. And then here's what they say about how their search for a solution started. Here's what they told us about how they started to do that research or find a solution."
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Gives an actionable template for mapping customer behavior, pain, and search triggers once you segment by the job-to-be-done.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing the map: KPIs, activation, win-backs
quotes.text: And the answers to that question are going to tell you what your first value should look like, which of that first product activation experience, whatever language you like to use, what should that look like for them? What parts of the product do you need to push right up to the front of that experience so they can get to it really, really quickly after they sign up?
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Connects customer research directly to designing the activation/first-value experience by front-loading the features that create the “convinced” moment.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing the map: KPIs, activation, win-backs
quotes.text: There should be a KPI for each of those stages in that customer journey.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A simple operational rule for turning a journey map into measurable execution across the funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing the map: KPIs, activation, win-backs
quotes.text: Generally, what we do there is, we can associate basically what they told us brings them the most amount of value with the product attribute or parts of the product that deliver that value. We try to tie the KPI obviously to some sort of meaningful product usage of that key part of the product or product attribute.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Provides a method for defining activation/engagement metrics: map stated value drivers to specific product usage signals.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing the map: KPIs, activation, win-backs
quotes.text: So lists were a specific feature that honestly, it was in there, but they weren't front loading the product experience with that. I'm not going to say it was hidden, but it wasn't front and center enough.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A concrete example of using research to identify high-value features that should be moved earlier in onboarding.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing the map: KPIs, activation, win-backs
quotes.text: I mean there's a lot of stats on the percentage. I think it's like 70% of people log into an app, log into a product once and never come back. It's wild.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A striking retention data point that motivates building win-back/re-engagement flows instead of assuming users will return.

quotes.topic_title: SparkToro KPI examples for activation and value
quotes.text: Oh no, I would hope it's more like six.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A contrarian guideline to keep customer journey maps intentionally short to focus on only the essential steps.

quotes.topic_title: SparkToro KPI examples for activation and value
quotes.text: I'm always trying to bring it down lowest, only as long as it absolutely needs to be. I mean that goes for all pages, landing pages.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: Actionable advice to reduce complexity—apply ruthless simplification to journeys and conversion surfaces like landing pages.

quotes.topic_title: SparkToro KPI examples for activation and value
quotes.text: So the measure for success at that tip somebody over into evaluation is performing their first search.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A concrete KPI example that defines “evaluation” by a key product action rather than a traditional funnel step like signup.

quotes.topic_title: SparkToro KPI examples for activation and value
quotes.text: So that first value KPI, I think it was five plus searches, plus at least one list.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A specific activation metric that uses a multi-action threshold (not a single event) to indicate real first value.

quotes.topic_title: SparkToro KPI examples for activation and value
quotes.text: And then the next one, as I mentioned before, is a combination of actually three things.
quotes.speaker: Georgiana Laudi
quotes.context: A methodology for defining deeper engagement/value milestones as composite behaviors rather than isolated actions.
